description:
A light, minimally processed, tea made from leaves harvested traditionally in Fujian, dating back at least as long ago as the Song Dynasty. White tea is harvested in the spring, when the the buds are still unopened and covered with white hairs, hence the name. The main varieties of white tea are [white peony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bai_Mudan), [silver needle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baihao_Yinzhen), [sau mei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoumei_tea) (otherwise known as *longevity eyebrows*), and [gong-mei](https://teapedia.org/en/Gong_Mei) (otherwise known as *tribute eyebrows*).

**Preparation**

As white tea leaves are more delicate and less oxidized, they can be steeped in lower temperature water than the darker teas, 185-210 degrees Fahrenheit according to Simon Beckwith in [A Little Tea Book](https://inpursuitoftea.com/products/little-tea-book).

**Characters**

[白](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%99%BD) is *white*, and [茶](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%8C%B6) is [tea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tea)., so [白茶](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%99%BD%E8%8C%B6) is *white tea*.

images.place: Ping Pang Pong, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
Also known as *shao-mei tea*, the Mandarin pronunciation, this is a white tea produced mostly in the Fujian and Gaunxi regions. If your dim sum place serves a white tea, this is probably it. The name of this tea stems from the leaves' resemblance to the eyebrows of the Taoist deity of longevity.

**Characters**

[壽](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A3%BD) means *long life*, and [眉](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%9C%89) means *eyebrow*, so besides the Cantonese and Mandarin pronunciations, sometimes this tea is referred to in English with the literal translations *long life eyebrow tea* or *longevity eyebrow tea*.

images.place: Tea and Whisk, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
Similar in name an appearance (eyebrows) to sau,-mei tea, but rarer, harvested later and thus a higher grade.

**Characters**

[貢](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%B2%A2) is *tribute*, and [眉](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%9C%89) means *eyebrow*, so 貢眉 is  *tribute eyebrow tea*.

Silver needle tea, also listed by its Mandarin pronunciation [baihao yinzhen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baihao_Yinzhen), is the premium, meaning more expensive, white tea. It's harvested early, before the buds have opened.

**Characters**

[白](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%99%BD) is *white*, [毫](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%AF%AB) is *hair*, [銀](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%8A%80) is *silver*, and [針](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%87%9D) is *needle*, so the full name is *white hair silver needle*. *White hair* describes the downy exterior of the buds, while *silver needle* refers to the shape of the buds. But usually it's just 銀針 (*silver needle*).

White peony tea, also listed by its Mandarin pronunciation [bai mudan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bai_Mudan), is a white tea that is harvested with two leaves for each bud. The name *white peony* describes how the leaves unfurl when brewed.

**Characters**

[白](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%99%BD) means *white*, and [牡丹](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%89%A1%E4%B8%B9) means *peony*.
